data.title: Dust (2009)
data.meta_description: Elodie and Elias have been living by themselves ever since most of the human race has disappeared from the face of the earth. However, with the unexpected arrival of Gabriel, a boy a bit older than themselves, their harmonic relationship is about to come to an end.
data.text:
This slow and quiet film was hauntingly beautiful and it's a shame it's not better known or got a wider release. You can watch it on vimeo, though, if you're interested and I would highly recommend it!

The quiet dialogues and the breathtaking cinematography along with the beautiful soundtrack and the set design were so aesthetically pleasing to me, I could watch it again right now. I also really love apocalyptic movies where the focus is not the tragedy itself (we never get to know what actually happened here) but the aftermath; how people adapt and live on in the new world.

The depiction of the deserted landscape, where every street, car and house seems to have been overgrown and forgotten, and the feeling of complete solitude is what really got under my skin. The codependency between the twins, which was really well portrayed, also stems from the fact that there's no one else around anymore.
